ARABIC: بِّسْمِ ٱللَّهِ ٱلرَّحْمَٰنِ ٱلرَّحِيمِ وَٱلتِّينِ وَٱلزَّيْتُونِ

ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: By the fig and the olive
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_1: I CALL TO witness the Fig and the Olive,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: By the fig and the olive;
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_3: By the fig, by the olive,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: By oath of the fig and of the olive,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: I swear by the fig and the olive,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_7: By the fig and the olive
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: By the fig and the olive,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_9: By the Fig and the Olive,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: By the fig, by the olive,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_11: By the fig and the olive,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: By the Fig and the Olive,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: By the fig, and the olive,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: By the fig and the olive!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: By the fig and the olive.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: By the fig and the olive
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [95:1] By the fig and the olive, that is, the two [edible] foods — or [these denote the names of] two mountains in Syria on which these two foods grow —
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: And from his narration on the authority of Ibn 'Abbas that he said regarding the interpretation of Allah's saying (By the fig and the olive): '(By the fig and the olive) He says: Allah swears by the fig, this fig of yours, and the olive, this olive of yours; it is also said the fig and the olive refer to two mountains in Historic Syria; it is also said that the fig refers to the hill upon which Jerusalem is built while the olive refers to the mountain upon which Damascus is built,
